problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. What is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n + 3$ share a common factor greater than $1$?
solution:
By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align*}
\text{gcd}\,(9n-2,7n+3) &= \text{gcd}\,(9n-2-(7n+3),7n+3) \\
&= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3) \\
&= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3-3(2n-5)) \\
&= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,n+18) \\
&= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5-2(n+18),n+18) \\
&= \text{gcd}\,(-41,n+18).
\end{align*}Since $41$ is prime, it follows that $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ have a common factor greater than 1 only if $n+18$ is divisible by 41. The smallest such positive integer value of $n$ is $41-18=\boxed{23}$. Note that $9n-2 = 205 = 5 \times 41$ and $7n+3 = 164 = 4 \times 41$.
gpt_response:
To find the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ share a common factor greater than $1$, we can first find the greatest common divisor (GCD) of the two expressions.

We can use the Euclidean algorithm to calculate the GCD:

\begin{align*}
\text{GCD}(9n-2, 7n+3) &= \text{GCD}(9n-2 - 7n+3, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(2n+5, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(2n+5 - 3(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(2n+5 - 21n-9, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-19n-4, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-19n-4 - 2(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-19n-4 - 14n-6, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-33n-10, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-33n-10 - 4(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-33n-10 - 28n-12, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-61n-22, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-61n-22 - 8(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-61n-22 - 56n-24, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-117n-46, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-117n-46 - 16(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-117n-46 - 112n-48, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-229n-94, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-229n-94 - 32(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-229n-94 - 224n-96, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-453n-190, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-453n-190 - 64(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-453n-190 - 448n-192, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-901n-382, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-901n-382 - 128(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-901n-382 - 896n-384, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-1797n-766, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-1797n-766 - 256(7n+3), 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-1797n-766 - 1792n-768, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-3589n-1534, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(-724(5n+2)-14, 7n+3) \\
&= \text{GCD}(14, 7n+3) \\
&= 14
\end{align*}

From the above calculations, we can see that the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ share a common factor greater than $1$ is when the GCD is $14$. This means that $n$ should be chosen such that both $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ are divisible by $14$. We can easily find such an $n$ by trial and error:

If $n=16$, then $9n-2 = 9(16)-2 = 142$ and $7n+3 = 7(16)+3 = 115$ do not have a common factor greater than $1$, since their GCD is $1$.

If $n=17$, then $9n-2 = 9(17)-2 = 151$ and $7n+3 = 7(17)+3 = 122$ do not have a common factor greater than $1$, since their GCD is $1$.

If $n=18$, then $9n-2 = 9(18)-2 = 160$ and $7n+3 = 7(18)+3 = 129$ do not have a common factor greater than $1$, since their GCD is $1$.

If $n=19$, then $9n-2 = 9(19)-2 = 163$ and $7n+3 = 7(19)+3 = 136$ do not have a common factor greater than $1$, since their GCD is $1$.

If $n=20$, then $9n-2 = 9(20)-2 = 178$ and $7n+3 = 7(20)+3 = 143$ have a common factor greater than $1$ since their GCD is $1$. Therefore, the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ share a common factor greater than $1$ is $n=20$.
